data_findings.finding: This is a 2D polygon packing optimization problem. Goal: pack Christmas tree shapes (15-vertex polygons) into smallest square bounding box for N=1 to 200 trees. Score = Σ(s_n²/n) where s_n is side length. Lower is better. Target: beat 68.919154.

bbox3.cpp is the core optimizer used by top solutions. Features: Complex Number Vector Coordination, Fluid Dynamics simulation, Hinge Pivot mechanism, Density Gradient Flow, Global Boundary Tension, OpenMP parallelization. Key params: -n iterations (5000-20000), -r rounds (16-256).

fix_direction post-processing: After optimization, rotate entire configuration to minimize bounding box. Uses ConvexHull of all tree vertices, then minimize_scalar to find optimal rotation angle between 0-90 degrees. Can improve score by reducing bounding box side.

tree_packer_v21.cpp: Alternative optimizer with swap moves, multi-angle restarts, higher temperature SA. Uses long double precision. Includes squeeze, compaction, and local search phases. Also has backward propagation (bp.cpp) to improve smaller N configs by removing trees from larger ones.

Top kernels use pre-optimized submissions as starting points: 'bucket-of-chump/submission.csv' and 'santa-2025-csv/santa-2025.csv'. These contain already-optimized configurations that can be further improved.

Christmas tree geometry: 15-vertex polygon with trunk (w=0.15, h=0.2), base tier (w=0.7), middle tier (w=0.4), top tier (w=0.25), tip at y=0.8. Total height 1.0. Can be positioned (x,y) and rotated by angle (deg).
